The term la usually applied to a quantity of these metals ready for tlie mint, but as yet lying in bars, plates, lumps, or other masses; but it may also include orna-ments or dishes of gold and silver, or foreign coins not current as money, when intended to be descriptive of its adaptability to be coined, and not of other purposes to which it may be put. Hope Min. Co. v. Kennon, 3 Mont. 44; Thalheim v. State, 38 Fin. 169, 20 South. 938; Counsel v. Min. Co., 5 Daly (N. Y.) 77

title: Bum-Bailiff
body: A person employed to dun one for a debt; a bailiff employed to ar-rest a debtor. Probably a vulgar corruption of “bound-bailiff,” (q. r.)

title: Bunda
body: In old English iaw. A bound, boundary, border, or limit, (terminus, limes

title: Buoy
body: In maritime law. A piece of wood or cork, or a barrel, raft, or other thlng, made secure and floating upon a stream or bay, intended as a guide and warning to mariners, by marking a spot where the water is shallow, or where there is a reef or other danger to navigation, or to murk the course of a devious channel

title: Burden Of Proof
body: (Lat. onus probandi.) In the law of evldence. The neces-slty or duty of affirmatively provlng a fact or facts in dispute on an issue raised between the parties In a cause, willett v. Rich, 142 Mass. 356, 7 N. E. 776, 56 Am. Rep. 684; wilder v. Cowles, 100 Mass. 490; People v. McCann, 16 N. Y. 58, 69 Am. Dec. 642

title: Bureau
body: An ofiice for the transaction of business. A name given to the several departments of the executive or admin istra-tive branch of government, or to their larger subdivisions. In re Strawbridge, 39 Ala. 375

title: Bureaucracy
body: A system in which the business of government is carried on in departments, each under the control of a chief, in contradistinction from a system in which the officers of government have a co-ordinate authority

title: Burg, Burgh
body: A term anciently ap-plied to a castle or fortified place; a borough, (q. v.) Spelman

title: Burgage
body: A name anciently given to a dwelling-house in a borough town. Blount

title: Burgage-Holding
body: A tenure by which lands in royal boroughs in Scotland were held of the sovereign. The service was watching and warding, and was done by the burgesses within the territory of the bor-ough, whether expressed in the charter or not

title: Burgage-Tenure
body: In English law. one of the three species of free socage hold-lngs; a tenure whereby houses and lands which were formerly the site of houses, in an ancient borough, are held of some lord by a certaln rent. There are a great many cus-toms affecting these tenures, the most re

title: Burgator
body: one who breaks into houses or inclosed places, as distinguished from one who committed robbery in the open country. Spelman

title: Burgbote
body: In old Engllsh law. A term applied to a contribution towards the repair of castles or walls of defense, or of a borough

title: Bubgenses
body: In old English law. In-habitants of a burg us or borough; burgesses. Fleta, lib. 5, c. 6, $ 10

title: Burgeristh
body: A word used in Domes-day, signifying a breach o/ the peace in a town. Jacob

title: Burgess
body: In English law. An inhabitant or freeman of a borough or town; a person duly and legally admitted a member of a municipal corporation. Spelman; 3 Steph. Comm. 188, 189

title: Burgess Roll
body: A roll, required by the St. & 6 wm. IV. c. 76, to be kept In corporate towns or boroughs, of the names of burgesses entitled to certain new rights •conferred by that act

title: Burgh-Breche
body: A fine imposed on the community of a town, for a breach of the peace, etc

title: Burgh English
body: See Borough Enq-LISIL

title: Burgh Engloys
body: Borough English, (q. v

title: Burghmails
body: Yearly payments to the crown of Scotland, Introduced by Malcolm III., and resembling the English fee-farm rents

title: Burghmote
body: In Saxon law. A court of Justice held semi-annually by the bishop or lord in a burg, which the thanes were bound to attend without summons

title: Burglariously
body: In pleading. A technical word which must be introduced into an Indictment for burglary at common law. Lewis v. State, 16 Conn. 34; Reed v. State, 14 Tex. App. 665

title: Burglariter
body: L. Lat. (Burglarious-Iy.) In old criminal pleading. A necessary word in Indictments for burglary

title: Burglary
body: In criminal law. The breaking and entering the house of another in the night-time, with intent to commit a felony therein, whether the felony be actual-ly committed or not. Anderson v. State, 48 Ala. 666, 17 Am. Rep. 36; Benson v. McMahon, 127 U. S. 457, 8 Sup. Ct 1240, 32 L. Ed. 234; IIunter v. State, 29 Ind. 80; State v. Petit, 32 wash. 129, 72 Pac. 1021; State v. Langford, 12 N. C. 253; State v. McCall, 4 Ala. 644, 39 Am. Dec. 314; State v. wilson, 1 N. J. Law, 439, 1 Am. Dec. 216; Com. v. Newell, 7 Mass. 245

title: Burgomaster
body: The title given In Germany to the chief executive officer of a borough, town, or city; corresponding to our “mayor

title: Burgundian Law
body: See Lex Bub-ouhdionum

title: Burgwhar
body: A burgess, (q. v

title: Burial
body: Sepulture; the act of interring dead human bodies. See Lay v. State, 12 Ind. App. 362, 39 N. E. 768; In re Reformed, etc., Church, 7 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 476; Cemetery Ass’n v. Assessors, 37 La. Ann. 35

title: Burking-Burkism
body: Murder committed with the object of selling the cadaver for purposes of dissection, particularly and originally, by suffocating or strangling the victim

title: Burlaws
body: In Scotch law. Laws made by neighbors elected by common consent in the burlaw courts. Skene

title: Burn
body: To consume with fire. The verb “to burn,” in an indictment for arson, is to be taken in its common meaning of “to con-sume with fire.” Hester v. State, 17 Ga. 130

title: Burning Fluid
body: As used in policies of insurance, this term does not mean any fluid which will burn, but it means a recog-nized article of commerce, called by that name, and which is a different article from naphtha or kerosene. Putnam v. Insurance Co. (C. C.) 4 Fed. 764; wheeler v. Insurance C0., 6 Mo. App. 235; Mark v. Insurance Co., 24 Hun (N. Y.) 569

title: Burning In The Hand
body: In old Eng-lish criminal law, laymen, upon being ac-corded the benefit of clergy, were burned with a hot iron in the brawn of the left thumb, in order that, being thus marked, they could not again claim thelr clergy. 4 Bl. Comm. 367

title: Burrochium
body: A burroch, dam, or small wear over a river, where traps are laid for the taking of fish. Cowell

title: Burrowmealis
body: In Scotch law. A term used to designate the rents paid into the king’s private treasury by the burgesses or inhabitants of a borough

title: Bursa
body: Lat A purse

title: Bursar
body: A treasurer of a college

title: Burs Aria
body: The exchequer of collegiate or conventual bodies; or the place of receiv-lng, paying, and accounting by the bursars. Also stipendiary scholars, who live upon the burse, fund, or joint-stock of the college

title: Burying Alive
body: In English law. The ancient punishment of sodomites, and those who contracted with Jews. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 27, $ 3

title: Burying-Ground
body: A place set apart for the Interment of the dead; a cemetery. Appeal Tax Court v. Academy, 50 Md. 353

title: Buscarl
body: In Saxon and old English law. Seamen or marines. Spelman

title: Bushel
body: A dry measure, containing four pecks, eight gallons, or thirty-two quarts. But the dimensions of a bushel, and the weight of a bushel of grain, etc., vary in the different states in consequence of statutory enactments. Richardson v. Spafford, 13 Vt

title: Business
body: This word embraces everything about which a person can be employed. People v. Com’rs of Taxes, 23 N. Y. 242, 244

title: Business Hours
body: Those hours of the day during which, in a given community, commercial, banking, professional, public, or oth-er kinds of business are ordinarily car-ried on

title: Busones Gomitatus
body: In old English law. The barons of a county

title: Butlerage
body: A privilege formerly al-lowed to the king’s butler, to take a certain part of every cask of wine imported by an alien

title: Butler'S Ordinance
body: In English law. A law for the heir to punish waste in the life of the ancestor. “Though it be on record in the parliament book of Edward I., yet it never was a statute, nor ever so received; but only some constitution of. the king's council, or lords in parliament, which never obtained the strength or force of an act of parliament.” Hale, Hist. Eng. Law, p. 18

title: Butt
body: A measure of liquid capacity, equal to oue hundred aud eight gallons; also a measure of land

title: Buttals
body: The hounding llnes of land at the end; abuttals, which see

title: Butted And Bounded
body: A phrase sometimes used in conveyancing, to introduce the boundaries of lauds. See Burrs and Bounds

title: Butts And Bounds
body: A phrase used in conveyancing, to describe the end lines or circumscribing lines of a certain piece of land. The phrase “metes and bounds” has the same meaning

title: Butty
body: A local term in the north of England, for the associate or deputy of another ; also of things used in common

title: By-Bidding
body: See Bid

title: By Bill, By Bill Without Writ
body: In practice. Terms anciently used to des-ignate actions commenced by original bill, as distinguished from those commenced by original writ, and applied in modern practice to suits commenced by capias ad respondendum. 1 Arch. Pr. pp. 2, 337; Harkness v. Harkness, 5 Hill (N. Y.) 213.

title: By Estimation
body: In conveyancing. A term used to indicate that the quantity of land as stated is estimated only, not exactly measured; has the same meaning and effect as the phrase "more or less.” Tarbell v. Bowman, 103 Mass. 341; Mendenhall v. Steckel, 47 Md. 453, 28 Am. Rep. 481; Hays v. Hays, 126 Ind. 92, 25 N. E. GOO, 11 L. R. A. 376

title: By God And My Country
body: In old

title: By-Laws
body: Regulations, ordinances, or rules enacted by a private corporation for its own government

title: By Law Men
body: In English law. The chief men of a town, representing the in-habitants

title: By-Road
body: The statute law of New Jer-sey recoguizes three different kinds of roads: A public road, a private road, aud a byroad. A by-road is a road used by the in-habitants, and recognized by statute, but not laid out. Such roads are often called “drift-ways.” They are roads of necessity in new-ly-settled countries. Van Blarcom v. Frike, 29 N. J. Law, 516. See, also, Stevens v. Allen, 29 N. J. Law, 68

title: By The By
body: Incidentally; without new process. A term used in former Engllsh practice to denote the method of filing a dec-laration against a defendant who was al-ready in the custody of the court at the suit of a different plaintiff or of the same plaintiff in another cause

title: Bye-Bil-Wuffa
body: In Hindu law. A deed of mortgage or conditional sale

title: Bail
body: The release, prior to trial, of a person accused of a crime, under specified conditions designed to assure that person's appearance in court when required. Also can refer to the amount of bond money posted as a financial condition of pretrial release.

title: Bankruptcy administrator
body: An officer of the Judiciary serving in the judicial districts of Alabama and North Carolina who, like the United States trustee, is responsible for supervising the administration of bankruptcy cases, estates, and trustees; monitoring plans and disclosure statements; monitoring creditor committees; monitoring fee applications; and performing other statutory duties.

title: Bankruptcy code
body: The informal name for title 11 of the United States Code (11 U.S.C. §§ 101-1330), the federal bankruptcy law.

title: Bankruptcy court
body: The bankruptcy judges in regular active service in each district; a unit of the district court.

title: Bankruptcy estate
body: All interests of the debtor in property at the time of the bankruptcy filing. The estate technically becomes the temporary legal owner of all of the debtor's property.

title: Bankruptcy judge
body: A judicial officer of the United States district court who is the court official with decision-making power over federal bankruptcy cases.

title: Bankruptcy petition
body: A formal request for the protection of the federal bankruptcy laws. (There is an official form for bankruptcy petitions.)

title: Bankruptcy trustee
body: A private individual or corporation appointed in all Chapter 7 and Chapter 13 cases to represent the interests of the bankruptcy estate and the debtor's creditors.

title: Bankruptcy
body: A legal procedure for dealing with debt problems of individuals and businesses; specifically, a case filed under one of the chapters of title 11 of the United States Code (the Bankruptcy Code).

title: Bench trial
body: A trial without a jury, in which the judge serves as the fact-finder.

title: Brief
body: A written statement submitted in a trial or appellate proceeding that explains one side's legal and factual arguments.

title: Burden of proof
body: The duty to prove disputed facts. In civil cases, a plaintiff generally has the burden of proving his or her case. In criminal cases, the government has the burden of proving the defendant's guilt. (See standard of proof.)

title: Business bankruptcy
body: A bankruptcy case in which the debtor is a business or an individual involved in business and the debts are for business purposes.
